# Pandas Basics Part 1 — Workbook *If you want to save your work from this notebook, you should be sure to make a copy of it on your own computer.* In this workbook, we're going to explore the basics of the Python library Pandas. ## Import Pandas To use the Pandas library, we first need to `import` it. ::: {.cell ExecuteTime='{"end_time":"2022-11-07T10:49:29.141374Z","start_time":"2022-11-07T10:49:28.852940Z"}' execution_count=1} ``` {.python .cell-code} import pandas as pd ``` ::: ## Change Display Settings By default, Pandas will display 60 rows and 20 columns. I often change [Pandas' default display settings](https://pandas.pydata.org/pandas-docs/stable/user_guide/options.html) to show more rows or columns. ::: {.cell ExecuteTime='{"end_time":"2022-11-07T10:49:29.441535Z","start_time":"2022-11-07T10:49:29.436047Z"}' execution_count=2} ``` {.python .cell-code} pd.options.display.max_rows = 200 ``` ::: ## Get Data To read in a CSV file, we will use the method `pd.read_csv()` and insert the name of our desired file path. ::: {.cell ExecuteTime='{"end_time":"2022-11-07T10:49:30.087045Z","start_time":"2022-11-07T10:49:30.022183Z"}' execution_count=3} ``` {.python .cell-code} pd.read_csv('../data/Bellevue_Almshouse_Dataset.csv') ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=3} ```{=html}

``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell ExecuteTime='{"end_time":"2022-11-07T10:49:30.224341Z","start_time":"2022-11-07T10:49:30.192133Z"}' execution_count=4} ``` {.python .cell-code} type(pd.read_csv('../data/Bellevue_Almshouse_Dataset.csv')) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=4} ``` pandas.core.frame.DataFrame ``` ::: ::: This creates a Pandas [DataFrame object](https://pandas.pydata.org/pandas-docs/stable/user_guide/dsintro.html#dataframe), one of the two main data structures in Pandas. A DataFrame looks and acts a lot like a spreadsheet, but it has special powers and functions that we will discuss below and in the next few lessons. | Pandas objects | Explanation | |----------|-------------------------------------| | `DataFrame` | Like a spreadsheet, 2-dimensional | | `Series` | Like a column, 1-dimensional | We assign the DataFrame to a variable called `bellevue_df`. It is common convention to name DataFrame variables `df`, but we want to be a bit more specific. ::: {.cell ExecuteTime='{"end_time":"2022-11-07T10:49:30.604532Z","start_time":"2022-11-07T10:49:30.561028Z"}' execution_count=5} ``` {.python .cell-code} bellevue_df = pd.read_csv('../data/Bellevue_Almshouse_Dataset.csv') ``` ::: ## Begin to Examine Patterns ### Select Columns as Series Objects `[]` To select a column from the DataFrame, we will type the name of the DataFrame followed by square brackets and a column name in quotations marks. ::: {.cell ExecuteTime='{"end_time":"2022-11-07T10:49:31.323120Z","start_time":"2022-11-07T10:49:31.311581Z"}' execution_count=6} ``` {.python .cell-code} bellevue_df['age'] ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=6} ``` 0 28.0 1 19.0 2 60.0 3 32.0 4 21.0 ... 9593 69.0 9594 47.0 9595 29.0 9596 4.0 9597 32.0 Name: age, Length: 9598, dtype: float64 ``` ::: ::: Technically, a single column in a DataFrame is a [*Series* object](https://pandas.pydata.org/pandas-docs/stable/user_guide/dsintro.html#dsintro). ::: {.cell ExecuteTime='{"end_time":"2022-11-07T10:49:31.729890Z","start_time":"2022-11-07T10:49:31.720341Z"}' execution_count=7} ``` {.python .cell-code} type(bellevue_df['age']) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=7} ``` pandas.core.series.Series ``` ::: ::: ## Pandas Methods | Pandas method | Explanation | |----------|-------------------------------------| | `.sum()` | Sum of values | | `.mean()` | Mean of values | | `.median()` | Median of values | | `.min()` | Minimum | | `.max()` | Maximum | | `.mode()` | Mode | | `.std()` | Unbiased standard deviation | | `.count()` | Total number of non-blank values | | `.value_counts()` | Frequency of unique values | ### ❓ How old (on average) were the people admitted to the Bellevue Almshouse? ::: {.cell ExecuteTime='{"end_time":"2022-11-07T10:49:32.564079Z","start_time":"2022-11-07T10:49:32.550970Z"}' execution_count=8} ``` {.python .cell-code} bellevue_df['age'] ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=8} ``` 0 28.0 1 19.0 2 60.0 3 32.0 4 21.0 ... 9593 69.0 9594 47.0 9595 29.0 9596 4.0 9597 32.0 Name: age, Length: 9598, dtype: float64 ``` ::: ::: ### ❓ How old was the oldest person admitted to Bellevue? ::: {.cell ExecuteTime='{"end_time":"2022-11-07T10:49:32.961111Z","start_time":"2022-11-07T10:49:32.947864Z"}' execution_count=9} ``` {.python .cell-code} bellevue_df['age'] ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=9} ``` 0 28.0 1 19.0 2 60.0 3 32.0 4 21.0 ... 9593 69.0 9594 47.0 9595 29.0 9596 4.0 9597 32.0 Name: age, Length: 9598, dtype: float64 ``` ::: ::: ### ❓ How young was the youngest person? ::: {.cell ExecuteTime='{"end_time":"2022-11-07T10:49:33.379110Z","start_time":"2022-11-07T10:49:33.369253Z"}' execution_count=10} ``` {.python .cell-code} bellevue_df['age'] ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=10} ``` 0 28.0 1 19.0 2 60.0 3 32.0 4 21.0 ... 9593 69.0 9594 47.0 9595 29.0 9596 4.0 9597 32.0 Name: age, Length: 9598, dtype: float64 ``` ::: ::: ### ❓ What were the most common professions among these Irish immigrants? To count the values in a column, we can use the `.value_counts()` method. What patterns do you notice in this list? What seems strange to you?
